question: Question_05_(a)
statement:
If

\[F(x) = \int_0^x \ln(2+\sin t)\,dt\] and

\[G(y) = \int_y^0 \ln(2+\sin t)\,dt,\]

find $\displaystyle F'\left(\frac{\pi}2\right)$ and
$\displaystyle G'\left(\frac{\pi}2\right)$.
sols:
By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, if

\[F(x) = \int_0^x \ln(2 + \sin t) dt\]

then

\[\displaystyle F'(x) = \ln(2 + \sin x).\]

Similarly,

\[G(y) = \int_y^0 \ln(2 + \sin t) dt = - \int_0^y \ln(2 + \sin t) dt\]

so the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus tells us that

\[\displaystyle G'(y) = - \ln(2 + \sin y).\]

We now can evaluate

\[\displaystyle F'(\pi/2) = \ln(2 + \sin(\pi/2)) = \ln (2+1) = \ln 3\]
and

\[\displaystyle G'(\pi/2) = - \ln(2+\sin(\pi/2)) = -\ln (2+1) = - \ln 3.\]
hints:
Use a \emph{fundamental} theorem that connects integration and
differentiation.
